Sub-Section: - 1.a These directions shall be called the Reserve Bank of India (Digital Payment Security Controls) directions, 2021. - 1.b These directions shall come into effect six months from the day they are placed on the official website of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). However, in respect of instructions already issued either by Department of Payment and Settlement Systems (DPSS), Department of Regulation (DoR) or Department of Supervision (DoS) of RBI including those to select Regulated Entities (REs), by way of circular or advisory, the timeline would be with immediate effect or as per the timelines already prescribed.
Summary: The Reserve Bank of India (Digital Payment Security Controls) directions, 2021, take effect six months after being posted on the RBI's official website, with certain existing instructions effective immediately.
Action Item: Monitor the RBI's official website for the publication of the directions, and ensure compliance with existing instructions immediately.
Document Summary: The document outlines regulatory requirements, but specific details could not be extracted due to formatting issues.
Document Action Item: Conduct a manual review to identify and implement compliance actions.

Sub-Section: - 2.a The provisions of these directions shall apply to the following Regulated Entities (REs): - 2.a.i Scheduled Commercial Banks (excluding Regional Rural Banks); - 2.a.ii Small Finance Banks; - 2.a.iii Payments Banks; - 2.a.iv Credit card issuing NBFCs.
Summary: The provisions apply to Scheduled Commercial Banks, Small Finance Banks, Payments Banks, and Credit card issuing NBFCs.
Action Item: Verify if your organization qualifies as a Regulated Entity under these provisions.

Sub-Section: - 3. All expressions unless defined herein shall have the same meaning as have been assigned to them under the Banking Regulation Act, 1949, Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934, Payment and Settlement Systems Act, 2007 or Information Technology Act, 2000/Information Technology (Amendment) Act, 2008 and Rules made thereunder, any statutory modification or re-enactment thereto or as used in commercial parlance, as the case may be.
Summary: Definitions provided refer to terms as per specified Indian regulatory acts and customary usage.
Action Item: Ensure that all relevant terms are understood and utilized in compliance with referenced acts.

Section: Governance and Management of Security Risks
Sub-Section: - 4.REs shall formulate a policy for digital payment products and services with the approval of their Board. The contours of the policy, while discussing the parameters of any “new product” including its alignment with the overall business strategy and inherent risk of the product, risk management/mitigation measures, compliance with regulatory instructions, customer experience, etc., should explicitly discuss about payment security requirements from Functionality, Security and Performance (FSP) angles such as: - 4.a Necessary controls to protect the confidentiality of customer data and integrity of data and processes associated with the digital product/services offered; - 4.b Availability of requisite infrastructure e.g. human resources, technology, etc. with necessary back up; - 4.c Assurance that the payment product is built in a secure manner offering robust performance ensuring safety, consistency and rolled out after necessary testing for achieving desired FSP; - 4.d Capacity building and expansion with scalability (to meet the growth for efficient transaction processing); - 4.e Minimal customer service disruption with high availability of systems/channels (to have minimal technical declines); - 4.f Efficient and effective dispute resolution mechanism and handling of customer grievance; and - 4.g Adequate and appropriate review mechanism followed by swift corrective action, in case any one of the above requirements is hampered or having high potential to get hampered. The Board and Senior Management shall be responsible for implementation of this policy. The policy shall be reviewed periodically, at least on a yearly basis. REs may formulate this policy separately for its different digital products or include the same as part of their overall product policy. Further, the policy document should require that every digital payment product/services offered addresses the mechanics, clear definition of starting point, critical intermittent stages/points and end point in the digital payment cycle, security aspects, validations till the digital payment is settled, clear pictorial representation of digital path and exception handling. In addition, signing off of the above requirements, mechanism for carrying out User Acceptance Tests (UAT) in multiple stages before roll out, sign off from multiple stakeholders (post UAT) and data archival requirements shall also be taken into account. The need for an external assessment of the entire process including the logic, build and security aspects of the application(s) supporting the digital product should be clearly articulated.
Summary: Regulated Entities (REs) must create a comprehensive policy for digital payment products with Board approval, outlining security requirements and review mechanisms.
Action Item: Develop and approve a digital payment policy addressing specified security and performance criteria by the Board.

Sub-Section: - 5.REs shall incorporate appropriate processes into their governance and risk management programs for identifying, analysing, monitoring and managing the specific risks, including compliance risk and fraud risk, associated with the portfolio of digital payment products and services on a continual basis and in a holistic manner. The Board/Senior Management of REs shall have appropriate performance monitoring systems/key performance indicators for assessing whether the product or service offered through digital payment channels meet operational and security norms.
Summary: Regulated entities must integrate processes for continuous identification, analysis, monitoring, and management of compliance and fraud risks related to digital payment products, with oversight from senior management using performance monitoring systems.
Action Item: Establish and implement risk management processes and performance monitoring systems for digital payment services by executive oversight.

Sub-Section: - 6.As part of this process, the REs shall define product-level limits on the level of acceptable security risk, document specific security objectives and performance criteria including quantitative benchmarks for evaluating the success of the security built into the digital payment product or service, periodically compare actual results with projections and qualitative benchmarks to detect and address adverse trends or concerns in a timely manner and modify the business plan/strategy involving the product, when appropriate, based on the security performance of the product or service.
Summary: Organizations must define and document acceptable security risks, performance criteria, and benchmarks for digital payment products, while regularly comparing these metrics to actual outcomes to address any adverse trends promptly.
Action Item: Establish product-level security risk limits and performance benchmarks, then implement a process for periodic evaluation.

Sub-Section: - 7.REs shall have trained resources with necessary expertise to manage the digital payment infrastructure. Wherever the REs are dependent on third party service providers, adequate oversight and controls for monitoring the activities of the third party personnel, in line with RBI guidelines on outsourcing, shall be put in place.
Summary: Reporting entities must ensure trained resources manage digital payment infrastructure and implement adequate oversight for third-party service provider activities as per RBI guidelines.
Action Item: Establish a training program for resources and develop oversight protocols for third-party service providers.

Sub-Section: - 8.REs shall conduct risk assessments with regard to the safety and security of digital payment products and associated processes and services as well as suitability and appropriateness of the same vis-à-vis the target users, both prior to establishing the service(s) and regularly thereafter. The risk assessment should take into account - 8.a The technology stack and solutions used; - 8.b Known vulnerabilities at each of the touchpoints of the digital product and the remedial action taken by the entity; - 8.c Dependence on third party service providers and oversight over such providers; - 8.d Risk arising out of integration of digital payment platform with other systems both internal and external to the RE, including core systems and systems of payment systems operators, etc.; - 8.e The customer experience, convenience and technology adoption required to use such products; - 8.f Reconciliation process; - 8.g Interoperability aspects; - 8.h Data storage, security and privacy protection as per extant laws/instructions; - 8.i Operational risk including fraud risk; - 8.j Business continuity and service availability; - 8.k Compliance with extant cyber security requirements; and - 8.l Compatibility aspects. Such assessment shall cover the surrounding ecosystem as well. The assessment of risks shall address the need to protect and secure payment data and evaluate the resilience of systems. The internal Risk and Control Self-Assessment (RCSA) exercise shall cover the risks (inherent) & controls vis-à-vis the probability and impact of threats to arrive at residual risk. In such an exercise, it is imperative for REs to maintain database of all systems and applications storing customer data in the payment ecosystem and compliance with applicable PCI standards in each of the systems (notwithstanding mandatory requirements of certification/standard accreditation).
Summary: REs must conduct comprehensive risk assessments of digital payment products and associated processes both before launching and regularly thereafter, considering various risk factors and compliance with PCI standards.
Action Item: Establish a schedule for regular risk assessments of digital payment products and maintain a database of all systems storing customer data.

Sub-Section: - 9.REs shall evaluate the risks associated with the chosen technology platforms, application architecture, both on the server and client side. Further, REs should undertake a review of the risk scenarios and existing security measures based on incidents affecting their services, before any major change to the infrastructure or procedures is made or, when, any new threats are identified through risk monitoring activities. Further, unused or unwanted features of the platform should be closely controlled to minimize risk.
Summary: Organizations must evaluate risks of technology platforms and architecture, review existing security measures against incidents, and control unused features before major infrastructure changes or upon identifying new threats.
Action Item: Conduct a comprehensive risk evaluation of current technology platforms and application architectures for potential threats.

Sub-Section: - 10.REs shall develop sound internal control systems and take into account the operational risk before offering digital payment products and related services. This would include ensuring that adequate safeguards are in place to protect integrity of data, customer confidentiality and security of data.
Summary: Entities must establish robust internal control systems to manage operational risk when offering digital payment products, ensuring data integrity and customer confidentiality.
Action Item: Develop and implement an internal control system that includes safeguards for data integrity and security before launching digital payment services.

Sub-Section: - 11.REs shall ensure that the digital payment architecture is robust and scalable, commensurate with the transaction volumes and customer growth. The IT strategy of the RE shall ensure that a robust capacity management plan is in place to meet evolving demand. REs shall also put in place review mechanism of IT/IT Security architecture and technology platform overhaul on a periodic basis based on Board-approved policy.
Summary: REs must establish a robust capacity management plan and regularly review their IT and security architectures according to Board-approved policies.
Action Item: Develop and implement a capacity management plan and set up a mechanism for periodic reviews of the IT/IT Security architecture.

Sub-Section: - 12.REs shall have necessary capacity, systems and procedures in place to periodically test the backed-up data, application pertaining to digital products to ensure recovery without loss of transactions or audit-trails. These facilities should be tested at least on a half-yearly basis for digital payment products and services.
Summary: Organizations must periodically test backup data and systems for digital payment products to ensure transaction recovery without loss.
Action Item: Schedule and conduct half-yearly tests of backup data for digital payment products and services.

Sub-Section: - 13.The communication protocol in the digital payment channels (especially over Internet) shall adhere to a secure standard. An appropriate level of encryption and security shall be implemented in the digital payment ecosystem.
Summary: The communication protocols in digital payment channels must comply with secure standards, ensuring adequate encryption and security measures are in place.
Action Item: Implement secure communication protocols and encryption standards in all digital payment channels.

Sub-Section: - 14.Web applications providing the digital payment products and services should not store sensitive information in HTML hidden fields, cookies, or any other client-side storage to avoid any compromise in the integrity of the data.
Summary: Web applications offering digital payment products must avoid storing sensitive information in HTML hidden fields, cookies, or client-side storage to safeguard data integrity.
Action Item: Review web application architecture to ensure sensitive information is not stored in insecure client-side locations.

Sub-Section: - 15.REs shall implement Web Application Firewall (WAF) solution and DDoS mitigation techniques to secure the digital payment products and services offered over Internet.
Summary: Entities must implement a Web Application Firewall (WAF) solution and DDoS mitigation techniques to protect digital payment products and services offered online.
Action Item: Deploy WAF and DDoS mitigation strategies for all digital payment services.

Sub-Section: - 16.The key length (for symmetric/asymmetric encryption, hashing), algorithms (for encryption, signing, exchange of keys, creation of message digest, random number generators), cipher suites, digital certificates and applicable protocols used in transmission channels, processing of data, authentication purpose, shall be strong, adopting internationally accepted and published standards that are not deprecated/demonstrated to be insecure/vulnerable and the configurations involved in implementing such controls are in general, compliant with extant instructions and the law of the land.
Summary: Organizations must ensure the use of strong encryption standards and protocols that comply with accepted international standards and current legal requirements.
Action Item: Review and update encryption configurations to align with current international standards and legal regulations.

Sub-Section: - 17.REs shall renew their digital certificates used in digital payment ecosystem well in time.
Summary: Entities must renew their digital certificates used in the digital payment ecosystem timely to ensure continued secure operations.
Action Item: Establish a renewal schedule for digital certificates to ensure they are renewed well before expiration.

Sub-Section: - 18.The mobile application and internet banking application should have effective logging and monitoring capabilities to track user activity, security changes and identify anomalous behaviour and transactions.
Summary: Mobile and internet banking applications must implement effective logging and monitoring to track user activities and identify anomalies.
Action Item: Implement logging and monitoring capabilities for mobile and internet banking applications.

Sub-Section: - 19.REs shall implement multi-tier application architecture, segregating application, database and presentation layer in the digital payment products and services.
Summary: Entities must implement a multi-tier application architecture that separates application, database, and presentation layers in their digital payment products and services.
Action Item: Design and implement a multi-tier architecture in all digital payment applications to enhance security.

Sub-Section: - 20.REs shall follow a ‘secure by design’ approach in the development of digital payment products and services. REs shall ensure that digital payment applications are inherently more secure by embedding security within their development lifecycle.
Summary: REs must adopt a 'secure by design' approach in developing digital payment products to enhance security throughout the development lifecycle.
Action Item: Integrate security measures into the development lifecycle of all digital payment applications.

Sub-Section: - 21.REs shall explicitly define security objectives (including protection of customer information/data) during (a) requirements gathering, (b) designing, (c) development, (d) testing including source code review, (e) implementation, maintenance & monitoring and (f) decommissioning phases of the digital payment applications.
Summary: Organizations must define security objectives, including customer data protection, across various development phases of digital payment applications.
Action Item: Establish and document security objectives for each phase of development for digital payment applications.

Sub-Section: - 22.REs (including those partnering with other entities to co-brand/co-develop applications) shall adopt and incorporate a threat modelling approach during application lifecycle management into their policies, processes, guidelines and procedures.
Summary: Organizations must integrate a threat modelling approach into their application lifecycle management policies and procedures.
Action Item: Update policies and procedures to incorporate threat modelling practices for application lifecycle management.

Sub-Section: - 23.For digital payment applications that are licensed by a third party vendor, REs shall have an escrow arrangement for the source code for ensuring continuity of services in case the vendor defaults or is unable to provide services.
Summary: Organizations must establish an escrow arrangement for the source code of third-party licensed digital payment applications to ensure service continuity in the event of vendor default.
Action Item: Set up escrow arrangements with the third-party vendor for source code management.

Sub-Section: - 24.REs shall conduct security testing including review of source code, Vulnerability Assessment (VA) and Penetration Testing (PT) of their digital payment applications to assure that the application is secure for putting through transactions while preserving confidentiality and integrity of the data that is stored and transmitted. Such testing should invariably cover compliance with various standards like OWASP. If the source code is not owned by the RE, then, in such cases, the RE shall obtain a certificate from the application developer stating that the application is free of known vulnerabilities, malware and any covert channels in the code. In this context, - 24.a The VA shall be conducted at least on a half-yearly basis; PT shall be conducted at least on a yearly basis. In addition, VA/PT shall be conducted as and when any new IT Infrastructure or digital payment application is introduced or when any major change is performed in application or infrastructure; - 24.b Testing related to review of source code/certification shall be conducted/obtained. This shall continue on a yearly basis, if changes/upgrades have been made to the application during the year; - 24.c Testing/Certification should broadly address the objective that the product/version/module(s) functions only in a manner that it is intended to do, is developed as per the best secure design/coding practices and standards, addressing known flaws/threats due to insecure coding; and - 24.d Penal provisions shall be included by the RE into third-party contractual arrangements for any non-compliance by the application provider.
Summary: REs must conduct Vulnerability Assessment (VA) biannually and Penetration Testing (PT) annually on their digital payment applications, ensure source code reviews/certifications annually after changes, and include penal provisions in contracts for non-compliance by application providers.
Action Item: Schedule and perform the next VA and PT according to the outlined periodicity and obtain necessary certifications for any updates.

Sub-Section: - 25.REs may also run automated VA scanning tools to automatically scan all systems on the network that are critical, public facing or store customer sensitive data on a continuous/more frequent basis.
Summary: Organizations must utilize automated VA scanning tools to continuously scan critical, public-facing systems or those storing customer-sensitive data.
Action Item: Implement automated VA scanning tools for all relevant systems and ensure continuous monitoring.

Sub-Section: - 26.REs shall compare the results from earlier vulnerability scans to verify/ascertain that vulnerabilities are addressed either by patching, implementing a compensating control, or documenting and accepting the residual risk with necessary approval and that there is no recurrence of the known vulnerabilities. The identified vulnerabilities should be fixed in a time-bound manner.
Summary: Organizations must ensure that vulnerabilities identified in prior scans are addressed in a timely manner through patching, controls, or documented acceptance of risk.
Action Item: Compare current vulnerabilities with previous scans and resolve any identified issues promptly.

Sub-Section: - 27.REs shall ensure that all vulnerability scanning is performed in authenticated mode either with agents running locally on the system to analyse the security configuration or with remote scanners that are given administrative rights on the system being tested.
Summary: Organizations must conduct vulnerability scanning in authenticated mode using either local agents or remote scanners with administrative rights.
Action Item: Ensure vulnerability scanning is performed in authenticated mode per the guidelines specified.

Sub-Section: - 28.REs shall verify and thoroughly test the functionality (to validate whether the system meets the functional requirements/specifications) and security controls of payment products and services before its launch/moving to the production environment.
Summary: Organizations must verify and thoroughly test both functionality and security controls of payment products and services prior to deployment in a production environment.
Action Item: Conduct comprehensive functionality and security testing of payment products before their launch.

Sub-Section: - 29.REs shall institute a mechanism to actively monitor for the non-genuine/unauthorised/malicious applications (with similar name/features) on popular app-stores and the web and respond accordingly to bring them down.
Summary: Entities must establish a system to actively monitor and respond to non-genuine, unauthorized, or malicious applications on app stores and the web.
Action Item: Implement a monitoring mechanism for fraudulent applications on app stores and develop a response plan to address identified threats.

Sub-Section: - 30.The server at the RE’s end should have adequate checks and balances to ensure that no transaction is carried out through non-genuine/unauthorised digital payment products/applications and the authentication process is robust, secure and centralised.
Summary: The server must implement comprehensive checks to prevent transactions through unauthorized digital payment applications, ensuring a robust, secure, and centralized authentication process.
Action Item: Establish and maintain a secure and centralized authentication system to monitor and control digital payment transactions.

Sub-Section: - 31.The security controls for digital payment applications must focus on how these applications handle, store and protect payment data. The APIs for secure data storage and communication have to be implemented and used correctly in order to be effective. REs shall refer to standards such as OWASP-MASVS, OWASP-ASVS and other relevant OWASP standards, security and data protection guidelines in ISO 12812, threat catalogues and guides developed by NIST (including for Bluetooth and LTE security), for application security and other protection measures. Such testing has to necessarily verify for vulnerabilities including, but not limited to OWASP/OWASP Mobile Top 10, application security guidelines/requirements developed/shared by operating system providers/OEMs.
Summary: Security controls for digital payment applications must ensure the effective handling, storage, and protection of payment data by adhering to established standards and guidelines.
Action Item: Implement and verify security controls following OWASP and NIST guidelines to secure digital payment applications.

Sub-Section: - 32.REs shall redact/mask customer information such as account numbers/card numbers/other sensitive information when transmitted via SMS/e-mails.
Summary: Organizations must redact customer information such as account and card numbers when transmitting via SMS or email.
Action Item: Implement procedures to ensure redaction of sensitive customer information during transmission.

Sub-Section: - 33.In view of the proliferation of cyber-attacks and their potential consequences, REs should implement, except where explicitly permitted/relaxed, multi-factor authentication for payments through electronic modes and fund transfers, including cash withdrawals from ATMs/micro-ATMs/business correspondents, through digital payment applications. At least one of the authentication methodologies should be generally dynamic or non-replicable. [e.g., Use of One Time Password, mobile devices (device binding and SIM), biometric/PKI/hardware tokens, EMV chip card (for Card Present Transactions) with server-side verification could be termed either in dynamic or non-replicable methodologies.]
Summary: Regulatory entities must implement multi-factor authentication for electronic payments and fund transfers, requiring at least one dynamic or non-replicable authentication method.
Action Item: Ensure deployment of multi-factor authentication methods for all electronic payment systems by utilizing dynamic or non-replicable techniques by the end of Q4 2025.

Sub-Section: - 34.REs may also adopt adaptive authentication to select the right authentication factors depending on risk assessment, user risk profile and behaviour. Properly designed and implemented multi-factor authentication methods are more reliable and stronger fraud deterrents and are more difficult to compromise. The key objectives of multi-factor authentication are to protect the confidentiality of payment data as well as enhance confidence in digital payment by combating various cyber-attack mechanisms like phishing, keylogging, spyware/malware and other internet-based frauds targeted at REs and their customers. In this regard, - 34.a The implementation of appropriate authentication methodologies should be based on an assessment of the risk posed by the RE’s digital payment products and services. The risk should be evaluated in light of the type of customer (e.g., retail/corporate/commercial); the customer transactional requirements/pattern (e.g., bill payment, fund transfer), the sensitivity of customer information and the volume, value of transactions involved. - 34.b Beyond the technology factor, the success of a particular authentication method depends on appropriate policies, procedures, and controls. An effective authentication method should take into consideration customer acceptance, ease of use, reliable performance, scalability to accommodate growth, customer profile, location, transaction, etc., and interoperability with other systems. - 34.c To enhance online processing security, multi-factor authentication and alerts (like SMS, e-mail, etc.) should be applied in respect of all payment transactions (including debits and credits), creation of new account linkages (addition/modification/deletion of beneficiaries), changing account details or revision to fund transfer limits. In devising these security features, REs should take into account their efficacy and differing customer preferences for additional online protection. - 34.d The alerts and OTPs received by the customer for online transactions shall identify the merchant name, wherever applicable, rather than the payment aggregator through which the transaction was effected. - 34.e As an integral part of the multi-factor authentication architecture, REs should also implement appropriate measures to minimise exposure to a middleman attack which is more commonly known as a man-in-the-middle attack (MITM), man-in-the-browser (MITB) attack or man-in-the-application attack. This is to ensure, among other things, that the data in transit is secured and the transactions are authenticated only by genuine/authorised source/process. - 34.f An authenticated session, together with its encryption protocol, should remain intact throughout the interaction with the customer. Else, in the event of interference or in case the customer closes the application, the session should be terminated, and the affected transactions resolved or reversed out. The customer should be promptly notified about the status of the transaction by email, SMS or through other means.
Summary: REs must implement multi-factor authentication tailored to risk assessments to secure digital payments and protect against fraud.
Action Item: Conduct a risk assessment to implement appropriate multi-factor authentication methodologies for all payment transactions.

Sub-Section: - 35.REs should set down the maximum number of failed log-in or authentication attempts after which access to the digital payment product/service is blocked. They should have a secure procedure in place to re-activate the access to blocked product/service. The customer shall be notified for failed log-in or authentication attempts.
Summary: Organizations must establish a maximum number of failed authentication attempts for access to digital payment services and notify customers accordingly.
Action Item: Define and implement a maximum limit for failed log-in attempts and develop a secure procedure for re-activating blocked access.

Sub-Section: - 36.The REs shall document and implement the configuration aspects for identifying suspicious transactional behaviour in respect of rules, preventive, detective types of controls, mechanism to alert the customers in case of failed authentication, time frame for the same, etc.
Summary: Organizations must document and implement configurations to identify suspicious transactional behavior, including rules for preventive and detective controls, and mechanisms for alerting customers about failed authentication attempts.
Action Item: Create and implement a documentation plan for configuration aspects relating to suspicious transaction detection and customer alert mechanisms.

Sub-Section: - 37.System alerts shall be parameterised and monitored in terms of various applicable parameters. Such parameters, as applicable could be: transaction velocity (e.g., fund transfers, cash withdrawals, payments through electronic modes, adding new beneficiaries, etc.) in a short period, more so in the accounts of customers who’ve never used mobile app/internet banking/card ever (depending upon the type of payment channel), high risk merchant category codes (MCC) parameters, counterfeit card parameters (String of Invalid CVV/PINs indicates an account generation attack), new account parameters (excessive activity on a new account), time zones, geo-locations, IP address origin (in respect of unusual patterns, prohibited zones/rogue IPs), behavioural biometrics, transaction origination from point of compromise, transactions to mobile wallets/mobile numbers/VPAs on whom vishing fraud or other types of fraud is/are registered/recorded, declined transactions, transactions with no approval code, etc.
Summary: Organizations must parameterize and monitor system alerts based on various specified parameters related to transaction activities and risk indicators for fraud detection.
Action Item: Implement a monitoring system to parameterize alerts based on defined parameters by reviewing transaction patterns and risk factors.

Sub-Section: - 38.Fraud analysis shall be conducted to identify the reason for fraud occurrence and determine mechanism to prevent such frauds.
Summary: Fraud analysis must be conducted to identify causes of fraud and establish prevention mechanisms.
Action Item: Initiate a fraud analysis to determine causative factors and preventive measures.

Sub-Section: - 39.The staff, especially in the fraud control function, shall be educated about frauds and trained in the following skills and areas of expertise: - 39.a Fraud control tools and their usage; - 39.b Investigative techniques and procedures; - 39.c Cardholder and merchant education techniques to prevent fraud; - 39.d Scheme/Card operating regulations; - 39.e Data processing and analysis and liaising or communicating with law enforcement agencies; and - 39.f The requisite skills required to (i) set and update appropriate rules, (ii) monitor the exceptions thrown based on the rules on a continuous basis and take necessary actions promptly, (iii) communicate/escalate wherever required to appropriate authorities, and (iv) differentiate false positives from the rest.
Summary: Staff in the fraud control function must receive training in various fraud prevention skills and tools to effectively mitigate risk.
Action Item: Organize and conduct comprehensive fraud control training sessions for relevant staff.

Sub-Section: - 40.REs shall maintain updated contact details of service providers, intermediaries, external agencies and other stakeholders (including other REs) for coordination in incident response. REs shall put in place a mechanism with the stakeholders to update and verify such contact details. REs shall also formulate specific SOPs to handle incidents related to payment ecosystem to mitigate the loss either to the customer or RE.
Summary: Regulated entities must maintain and verify updated contact details of stakeholders for incident response, and establish SOPs to manage payment ecosystem-related incidents.
Action Item: Implement a system for updating and verifying contact details of all stakeholders and develop specific SOPs for payment ecosystem incidents.

Sub-Section: - 41.A real-time/near-real time (not later than 24 hours from the time of receipt of settlement file(s)) reconciliation framework for all digital payment transactions between RE and all other stakeholders such as payment system operators, business correspondents, card networks, payment system processors, payment aggregators, payment gateways, third party technology service providers, other participants, etc., shall be put in place for better detection and prevention of suspicious transactions. A mechanism shall be introduced to monitor the implementation and effectiveness of such framework.
Summary: Organizations must establish a real-time reconciliation framework for digital payment transactions within 24 hours of receiving settlement files to enhance detection and prevention of suspicious activities.
Action Item: Implement a real-time reconciliation framework for all digital payment transactions and ensure monitoring mechanisms are in place.

Sub-Section: - 42.REs shall incorporate secure, safe and responsible usage guidelines and training materials for end users within the digital payment applications. They shall also make it mandatory (i.e. not providing any option to circumvent/avoid the material) for the consumer to go through secure usage guidelines (even in the consumer’s preferred language) while obtaining and recording confirmation during the onboarding procedure in the first instance and first use after each update of the digital payment application or after major updates to secure and safe usage guidelines.
Summary: Organizations must ensure that end users engage with secure usage guidelines and training as part of onboarding and after major updates to digital payment applications.
Action Item: Implement mandatory training on secure usage guidelines for all users during onboarding and after each major update.

Sub-Section: - 43.REs shall mention/incorporate a section on the digital payment application clearly specifying the process and procedure (with forms/contact information, etc.) to lodge consumer grievances. A mechanism to keep this information periodically updated shall also be put in place. The reporting facility on the application shall provide an option for registering a grievance. Customer dispute handling, reporting and resolution procedures, including the expected timelines for the RE's response should be clearly defined.
Summary: Registered Entities must include a detailed section in their digital payment applications outlining the grievance process and maintain updated grievance information.
Action Item: Incorporate a grievance procedure section in the digital payment application and implement a mechanism for periodic updates.

Sub-Section: - 44.REs shall adhere to extant instructions, updated from time to time, to put in place system/s for online dispute resolution for resolving disputes and grievances of customers pertaining to digital payments.
Summary: Organizations must establish systems for online dispute resolution in compliance with updated instructions to address customer grievances related to digital payments.
Action Item: Implement online dispute resolution systems as per the latest instructions provided.

Sub-Section: - 45.REs shall educate customers about the need to maintain the physical and logical security of their devices accessing digital payment products and services including recommending secure/regular installation of operating system and application updates, downloading applications only from authorised sources, having anti-malware/anti-virus applications on devices, etc.
Summary: Entities must educate customers on maintaining the security of devices used for digital payment services, including installing updates, using authorized app sources, and having security software.
Action Item: Develop and implement a customer education program focused on device security best practices.

Sub-Section: - 46.REs shall ensure that its customers are provided information about the risks, benefits and liabilities of using digital payment products and its related services before they subscribe to them. Customers shall also be informed clearly and precisely on their rights, obligations and responsibilities on matters relating to digital payments, and, any problems that may arise from its service unavailability, processing errors and security breaches. The terms and conditions including customer privacy and security policy applying to digital payment products and services shall be readily available to customers within the product. All digital channels are to be offered on express willingness of customers and shall not be bundled without their knowledge.
Summary: Entities must provide customers with clear information about the risks, benefits, liabilities, and their rights regarding digital payment products before subscription.
Action Item: Ensure that all digital payment product disclosures regarding risks, benefits, liabilities, and customer rights are clearly documented and accessible before customer subscription.

Sub-Section: - 47.Whenever new operating features or functions, particularly those relating to security, integrity and authentication, are introduced to online delivery channels, clear and effective communication followed by sufficient instructions to properly utilise such new features should be provided to the customers.
Summary: Organizations must provide clear communication and sufficient instructions to customers when new security features are introduced for online delivery channels.
Action Item: Develop and disseminate communication materials outlining new security features and instructions to customers upon their introduction.

Sub-Section: - 48.REs may continuously create public awareness on the types of threats and attacks used against the consumers while using digital payment products and precautionary measures to safeguard against the same. Customers shall be cautioned against commonly known threats in recent times like phishing, vishing, reverse-phishing, remote access of mobile devices and educated to secure and safeguard their account details, credentials, PIN, card details, devices, etc.
Summary: Entities must continuously create public awareness regarding digital payment threats and precautions for consumers.
Action Item: Develop and distribute educational materials on digital payment security threats and protective measures.

Sub-Section: - 49.REs shall provide digital payment products and services, to a customer only at her/his option based on specific written or authenticated electronic requisition along with a positive acknowledgement of the terms and conditions.
Summary: Digital payment products and services must be provided to customers only upon their explicit written or authenticated electronic request, accompanied by acknowledgment of the terms and conditions.
Action Item: Ensure customers provide specific written or electronic requisition and acknowledgment before granting access to digital payment services.

Sub-Section: - 50.REs should provide a mechanism on their mobile and internet banking application for their customers to, with necessary authentication, identify/mark a transaction as fraudulent for seamless and immediate notification to his RE. On such notification by the customer, the REs may endeavour to build the capability for seamless/instant reporting of fraudulent transactions to the corresponding beneficiary/counterparty’s RE; vice-versa have mechanism to receive such fraudulent transactions reported from other REs. The objective of this mechanism is to accelerate early detection and enable the banking/payment system to trace the transaction trail and mitigate the loss to the defrauded customer at the earliest possible time.
Summary: REs must implement a mechanism in their banking applications for customers to report fraudulent transactions, facilitating immediate notification and reporting between REs.
Action Item: Develop and integrate a reporting mechanism in mobile and internet banking applications by Q4 2025.

Sub-Section: - 51.Internet banking websites are vulnerable to authentication related brute force attacks/application layer Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. Based on the RE’s individual risk/vulnerability assessment on authentication-related attacks such as brute force/DoS attacks, REs shall implement additional levels of authentication to internet banking websites such as adaptive authentication, strong CAPTCHA (preferably with anti-bot features) with server-side validation, etc., in order to plug this vulnerability and prevent its exploitation. Appropriate measures shall be taken to prevent DNS cache poisoning attacks and for secure handling of cookies. Virtual keyboard option should be made available.
Summary: REs must implement additional authentication measures and security controls for internet banking websites to mitigate vulnerabilities to brute force and DoS attacks, including adaptive authentication and strong CAPTCHA features.
Action Item: Implement adaptive authentication and strong CAPTCHA with anti-bot features on all internet banking websites by Q4 2025.

Sub-Section: - 52.An online session shall be automatically terminated after a fixed period of inactivity.
Summary: Online sessions must be automatically terminated after a specified period of inactivity.
Action Item: Implement session termination protocols for inactivity across online banking platforms.

Sub-Section: - 53.Secure delivery of password for login purpose shall be ensured. The password generated and dispatched by the RE should be valid for a limited period from the date of its creation. If the password is generated and dispatched by the RE, then, the user shall be compulsorily required to change the password, on the first login.
Summary: Organizations must ensure secure password delivery, enforce a time-limited validity for generated passwords, and require users to change their passwords upon first login.
Action Item: Implement a system for secure password generation and delivery, alongside a mandatory password change protocol on first login.

Sub-Section: - 54.When the internet banking application is accessed through external websites (e.g., in case of payment of taxes, e-commerce transactions, etc.), the procedure for authentication and the appearance/look and feel of the RE’s internet banking site should be made uniform as far as possible.
Summary: The authentication procedure and design of the internet banking application accessed via external websites must be standardized across all platforms.
Action Item: Ensure uniformity in the authentication process and visual design of the internet banking site across external access points.

Sub-Section: - 55.On detection of any anomalies or exceptions for which the mobile application was not programmed, the customer shall be directed to remove the current copy/instance of the application and proceed with installation of a new copy/instance of the application. REs shall be able to verify the version of the mobile application before the transactions are enabled.
Summary: Customers must uninstall their current mobile application version upon detection of any anomalies and install a new version, which should be verifiable by REs before transactions are enabled.
Action Item: Establish a protocol for directing customers to uninstall and reinstall the mobile application upon anomaly detection.

Sub-Section: - 56.Specific Controls for mobile applications include: - 56.a Device policy enforcement (allowing app installation/execution after baseline requirements are met); - 56.b Application secure download/install; - 56.c Deactivating older application versions in a phased but time bound manner (not exceeding six months from the date of release of newer version) i.e., maintaining only one version (excluding the overlap period while phasing out older version) of the mobile application on a platform/operating system; - 56.d Storage of customer data; - 56.e Device or application encryption; - 56.f Ensuring minimal data collection/app permissions; - 56.g Application sandbox/containerisation; - 56.h Ability to identify remote access applications (to the extent possible) and prohibit login access to the mobile application, as a matter of precaution; and - 56.i Code obfuscation.
Summary: Mobile applications must enforce specific controls, including device policy, secure download, phased deactivation of older versions within six months, and strict data handling practices.
Action Item: Implement the specified controls for mobile applications as per the outlined requirements.

Sub-Section: - 57.REs may consider to perform validation on the security and compatibility condition of the device/operating system and the mobile application to ensure that activities relating to the account are put through the mobile application in a safe and secure manner.
Summary: REs should validate the security and compatibility of devices and applications to ensure safe account activities.
Action Item: Implement a validation process for devices and applications involved in mobile payments.

Sub-Section: - 58.REs may explore the feasibility of implementing a code that checks if the device is rooted/jailbroken prior to the installation of the mobile application and disallow the mobile application to install/function if the phone is rooted/jailbroken.
Summary: Organizations should implement code that prevents installation or functioning of the mobile application on rooted or jailbroken devices.
Action Item: Develop and integrate a detection code to check for rooted/jailbroken status before mobile application installation.

Sub-Section: - 59.Checksum of current active version of application shall be hosted on public platform so that users can verify the same.
Summary: The current active version's checksum must be publicly accessible for user verification.
Action Item: Host the checksum of the current active application version on a public platform.

Sub-Section: - 60.REs shall ensure device binding of mobile application.
Summary: REs must implement device binding for mobile applications to enhance security.
Action Item: Ensure that device binding is integrated into the mobile application by testing and verifying its effectiveness.

Sub-Section: - 61.Considering that the additional factor of authentication and mobile application may reside on the same mobile device in the case of mobile banking, mobile payments, REs may consider implementing alternatives to SMS-based OTP authentication mechanisms.
Summary: Organizations are encouraged to consider alternatives to SMS-based OTP authentication mechanisms for mobile banking and payments due to potential security risks.
Action Item: Assess and implement alternative authentication methods beyond SMS-based OTP for mobile applications.

Sub-Section: - 62.The mobile application should require re-authentication whenever the device or application remains unused for a designated period and each time the user launches the application. Applications must be able to identify new network connections or connections from unsecured networks like unsecured Wi-Fi connections and must implement appropriate authentication/checks/measures to perform transactions under those circumstances.
Summary: Mobile applications must require re-authentication after inactivity and upon launch, while identifying new or unsecured network connections.
Action Item: Implement re-authentication measures in the mobile application to ensure compliance with inactivity and network connection checks.

Sub-Section: - 63.The mobile application should not store/retain sensitive personal/consumer authentication information such as user IDs, passwords, keys, hashes, hard coded references on the device and the application should securely wipe any sensitive customer information from memory when the customer/user exits the application.
Summary: The mobile application must not retain sensitive personal authentication information and should securely erase it from memory upon exit.
Action Item: Implement secure data handling protocols to prevent storage of sensitive information and ensure secure data wipe upon application exit.

Sub-Section: - 64.REs shall ensure that their mobile application limit the writing of sensitive information into ‘temp’ files. The sensitive information written in such files must be suitably encrypted/masked/hashed and stored securely.
Summary: Mobile applications must limit the writing of sensitive information into temporary files and ensure that such information is encrypted, masked, or hashed before secure storage.
Action Item: Implement controls to limit sensitive data writing in temp files and ensure proper encryption/masking/hashing methods are applied.

Sub-Section: - 65.REs may consider designing anti-malware capabilities into their mobile applications.
Summary: REs should consider incorporating anti-malware capabilities within their mobile applications to enhance security.
Action Item: Evaluate and design anti-malware solutions for all mobile applications.

Sub-Section: - 66.REs shall ensure that the usage of raw (visible) SQL queries in mobile applications to fetch or update data from databases is avoided. Mobile applications should be secured from SQL injection type of vulnerabilities. Sensitive information should be written to the database in an encrypted form. Web content, as part of the mobile application’s layout, should not be loaded if errors are detected during SSL/TLS negotiation. Certificate errors on account of the certificate not being signed by a recognised certificate authority; expiry/revocation of the certificate must be displayed to the user.
Summary: Mobile applications must avoid using raw SQL queries, encrypt sensitive data, and handle SSL/TLS negotiation errors appropriately to mitigate vulnerabilities.
Action Item: Implement measures to prevent raw SQL queries, ensure sensitive data is encrypted in the database, and establish error handling for SSL/TLS negotiation failures.

Sub-Section: - 67.REs shall follow various payment card standards (over and above PCI-DSS and PA-DSS) as per Payment Card Industry (PCI) prescriptions for comprehensive payment card security as per applicability/readiness of updated versions of the standards such as - 67.a PCI-PIN (secure management, processing, and transmission of personal identification number (PIN) data); - 67.b PCI-PTS (security approval framework addresses the logical and/or physical protection of cardholder and other sensitive data at point of interaction (POI) devices and hardware security modules (HSMs); - 67.c PCI-HSM (securing cardholder-authentication applications and processes including key generation, key injection, PIN verification, secure encryption algorithm, etc.); and - 67.d PCI-P2PE (security standard that requires payment card information to be encrypted instantly upon its initial swipe and then securely transferred directly to the payment processor).
Summary: Entities must adhere to multiple payment card standards and protocols for ensuring comprehensive security in card payments, including PCI-PIN, PCI-PTS, PCI-HSM, and PCI-P2PE, as applicable.
Action Item: Review and implement necessary measures to comply with the specified PCI standards for payment card security.

Sub-Section: - 68.REs should ensure that terminals installed at the merchants for capturing card details for payments or otherwise are validated against the PCI-P2PE program to use PCI-approved P2PE solutions; PoS terminals with PIN entry installed at the merchants for capturing card payments (including the double swipe terminals) are approved by the PCI-PTS program.
Summary: Merchants must ensure that terminals for capturing card details are validated against the PCI-P2PE program and that PoS terminals with PIN entry are approved by the PCI-PTS program.
Action Item: Verify and validate all terminals against the PCI-P2PE program and ensure PoS terminals have PCI-PTS approval.

Sub-Section: - 69.Acquirers shall secure their card payment infrastructure (Unique Key Per Terminal - UKPT or Derived Unique Key Per Transaction - DUKPT/Terminal Line Encryption - TLE).
Summary: Acquirers are required to secure their card payment infrastructure using UKPT or DUKPT/TLE methods.
Action Item: Implement UKPT or DUKPT/TLE security measures for card payment infrastructure.

Sub-Section: - 70.The security controls to be implemented at HSM are: - 70.a The HSMs should have logging enabled, the logs must themselves be tamper proof; - 70.b HSM can become a single point of failure. This needs to be mitigated by ‘clustering’ for high availability and ensure secure backups; - 70.c Access to the HSM should be controlled through Access Control Lists (ACLs); - 70.d Separate ACLs should be maintained for each individual application to ensure application level isolation; - 70.e All access to HSM should be managed and monitored using a robust Privileged Identity and Access Management solution; - 70.f Decryption and validation of keys, PIN should be done at HSM; - 70.g Card PIN generation and printing should be directly at system connected HSM; - 70.h CVV generation and validation should be done at HSM; - 70.i Ensure HSM is implemented with secure PIN block format with controls to disable outputting PIN block in weaker format; - 70.j Secure key management for HSMs (such as LMKs, etc.); and - 70.k Security of the physical keys of the HSM device should be properly maintained.
Summary: Organizations must implement comprehensive security controls for HSMs, including logging, access control, and secure key management.
Action Item: Establish and enforce security controls for HSMs, including logging, ACLs, and secure key management practices.

Sub-Section: - 71.REs shall implement the following for improving the security posture of the ATM: - 71.a Implement security measures such as BIOS password, disabling USB ports, disabling auto-run facility, applying the latest patches of operating system and other softwares, terminal security solution, time-based admin access, etc.; - 71.b Implement anti-skimming and whitelisting solution; and - 71.c Upgrade all the ATMs with supported versions of operating system. Use of ATMs that have unsupported operating systems shall be prohibited.
Summary: Regulated entities must enhance ATM security by implementing strict measures such as BIOS passwords, disabling USB ports, and upgrading to supported operating systems.
Action Item: Ensure all ATMs are upgraded to supported operating system versions and implement specified security measures by July 2025.

Sub-Section: - 72.REs shall ensure robust surveillance/monitoring of card transactions (especially overseas cash withdrawals) and setting up of rules and limits commensurate with their risk appetites. REs shall take up with the card network and/or ATM network as the case may be, to put in place transaction limits at Card, BIN as well as at the RE level. Such limits shall be mandatorily set at the card network switch itself. Limits could be mandated both for domestic as well as international transactions separately. REs shall put in place transaction control mechanisms with necessary caps (restrictions on transactions), if any of the limits set as per the above requirement is breached. A periodic review mechanism of such limits set as per the risk appetite of the RE shall be put in place as per the Board-approved policy. REs shall institute a mechanism to monitor breaches, if any, on a 24x7 basis, including weekends, long holidays and put in place a robust incident response mechanism to mitigate the fraud loss, on account of suspicious transactions, if any. REs shall ensure that card details of the customers are not stored in plain text at the RE and its vendor(s) locations, systems and applications. REs shall also ensure that the processing of card details in readable format is performed in a secure manner to strictly avoid data leakage of sensitive customer information.
Summary: REs must implement transaction surveillance for card transactions, set transaction limits according to risk appetite, review mechanisms for compliance, monitor breaches continuously, and ensure sensitive card details are secured and not stored in plain text.
Action Item: Establish transaction monitoring and limit-setting procedures in line with risk appetite and conduct regular reviews as per Board-approved policy.

Sub-Section: - 73.REs that use card data scanning tools to identify unencrypted (clear text) payments card data in their ecosystem especially during audits shall adhere to the following safety measures: - 73.a Any tool (procured by/from a third-party) for the purpose of scanning of unencrypted card data should first be tested in a test environment to understand the scope and impact of the tool’s capabilities; - 73.b The scanning tool should be installed only in the RE's premises on their devices; - 73.c Card data scanning should not be done remotely; - 73.d The discovered data, if any, must preferably reside in the scanning tool. Exportable card data must be appropriately masked. (No data, even masked, must be taken out of the RE’s premises/infrastructure); and - 73.e Limited access to service providers to conduct the scan or analyse the data, if at all, must be provided only on the RE’s devices.
Summary: Regulated entities must implement specific safety measures when using card data scanning tools to identify unencrypted payment card data.
Action Item: Ensure all scanning tools are tested in a controlled environment and installed only on the organization's premises, with access restrictions in place.
